DOCNAME: CASE OF TSERKVA SELA SOSULIVKA v. UKRAINE
CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection dismissed (applicability);Preliminary objection joined to merits and dismissed (non-exhaustion of domestic remedies);Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Karel Jungwiert;Margarita Tsatsa-Nikolovska;Mark Villiger;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste;Snejana Botoucharova;Volodymyr Butkevych
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant , the GPE ORG of the village of ORG in GPE ( ORG ) , is a religious group belonging to the patriarchate of the GPE ORG ( « PERSON греко-католицька церква села ORG області ORG ) . The head of the applicant association is its priest , Father PERSON .

CARDINAL . In accordance with a decision by ORG ( “ NORP Regional Administration ” ) on DATE , the applicant was entitled to use church LOC situated in the village of ORG in GPE ( “ церква PERSON Діви Марії у с. GPE ” ) for religious ceremonies . It was required to share the LOC with another church of ORG of the Kyiv Patriarchate ( “ ORG KP ” ; “ ORG Церкви Київського Патріархату ” ) . In accordance with paragraph CARDINAL of the decision , ORG of GPE ( “ ORG ” ) was to conclude separate agreements on the use of the church LOC and its property with religious denominations , specifying particular times , procedures and conditions for their use . The decision itself did not provide specific details on how the LOC and property were to be used .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant concluded agreement on the use of the church LOC with ORG and agreed to share it with the UOP KP on the conditions specified in this agreement . The agreement contained no details as to how the LOC were to be used . The applicant also alleged that the UOP KP continued to use the LOC without any agreement with ORG and impeded its own use of the LOC .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant requested ORG to transfer the church LOC to it for its sole use and its religious needs . It also informed ORG that the ORG KP had refused to comply with the decision of DATE and the agreement concluded with ORG on DATE . In reply , on DATE ORG of ORG informed the applicant that disputes over the use of religious LOC that had been transferred to religious organisations in accordance with agreements on their use were within the competence of ORG ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged complaints with ORG against ORG , seeking a transfer of the use of the church LOC , as specified in the agreement with ORG . In particular , the applicant stated that the church sharing the premises had failed to comply with the decision of DATE . It further stated that under section CARDINAL of the Freedom of Consciousness and Religious Organisations Act , the ORG as the owner had to manage the sharing and use of the church LOC on the basis of agreements with the occupiers .

CARDINAL . On DATE a judge of ORG rejected the applicant 's complaint on the ground that it should have been lodged with a court of general jurisdiction , not an arbitration court dealing with commercial matters . In particular , he referred to the fact that the applicant had complained about the lack of arrangements for the use of the LOC following the decision of ORG of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , sitting in a chamber composed of CARDINAL judges , examined the applicant 's request to review the case in the course of supervisory review proceedings and upheld the decision of DATE . In particular , it referred to section CARDINAL of the Freedom of Conscience and LAW of DATE , which stated that disputes over the use of religious LOC were to be examined under LAW by the courts of general jurisdiction and not by the arbitration ( commercial ) courts . It further mentioned that the decision of ORG was an “ enforceable document ” and could have been enforced in accordance with Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant appealed to the President of ORG seeking his intervention by means of a supervisory review appeal against the decisions of DATE and CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG ( as ORG was now called ) rejected the applicant 's request owing to the changes introduced to LAW , which made the ruling of CARDINAL DATE final and not subject to any appeal .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant instituted proceedings in ORG ( ORG міський суд ) , the local first instance court of general jurisdiction , against ORG for a transfer of the LOC to its sole use .

CARDINAL . On DATE the court rejected this claim , stating that the courts of general jurisdiction had no authority to deal with disputes between legal entities . It also made an order for the dispute to be referred to ORG , which , in its view , had jurisdiction over the matter . The applicant did not appeal in cassation and the ruling of CARDINAL DATE became final . Instead , it lodged a request with ORG for supervisory review of the ruling of CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused to initiate supervisory review proceedings in the case . In particular , the Deputy President of ORG informed the applicant that disputes between legal entities were within the jurisdiction of the arbitration courts and that there were thus no reasons for lodging a supervisory review appeal . He referred to ORG of the Code of Civil Procedure and LAW .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Deputy President of ORG refused to initiate supervisory review proceedings in the case , informing the applicant that disputes involving ownership claims over church LOC were within the jurisdiction of the commercial courts and disputes involving their use were to be examined by the local courts of general jurisdiction . It advised the applicant to clarify its claims .
CARDINAL . The applicant then instituted proceedings in ORG for the transfer of the premises to its sole use .

CARDINAL . On DATE the court refused to consider the applicant 's claims , referring to the ruling of DATE and the decision of the ORG of CARDINAL DATE by which the ORG had already resolved the dispute . The court also made reference to a practice direction that had been issued by the ORG on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG upheld the ruling of DATE . It also held that the commercial courts had no jurisdiction over the case as it did not concern property issues , but a challenge against a decision taken by a ORG body , which was a matter to be dealt with in the course of administrative , not judicial , proceedings .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused to institute cassation proceedings in the case having found no grounds for doing so .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW read as follows :

CARDINAL . In accordance with LAW , in force at the material time , that is to say before DATE , legal entities and private entrepreneurs engaged in business activities were entitled to apply to the arbitration courts , in accordance with the relevant jurisdictional rules , for the protection of their legal rights and interests . Any agreement waiving the right to apply to an arbitration court was deemed null and void .

CARDINAL . Under LAW in force before DATE , the arbitration courts had jurisdiction over commercial disputes involving execution of the commercial contracts and applications for orders declaring certain normative acts null and void . The following were excluded from the jurisdiction of the arbitration courts : disputes as to technical standards and conditions ; prices for particular products , services or goods ; bankruptcy cases ; and cases involving ORG or ORG . Disputes concerning the validity of legal acts or concerning public - procurement contracts were within the exclusive jurisdiction of the arbitration courts .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Code established that ORG had jurisdiction over complaints against ORG . In accordance with the rules on exclusive jurisdiction , under LAW , cases involving the enjoyment of possessions were to be examined in the arbitration court with jurisdiction for the area in which the property was situated . Under LAW , the court was required to transfer the case - file to another court which had jurisdiction over claims which had been lodged with the wrong court . A ruling on the transfer of the case to a different court on jurisdictional grounds could be reviewed in the course of supervisory review proceedings .
CARDINAL . The relevant extracts from the LAW , as amended on DATE , read as follows :
Transitional Provisions
“ CARDINAL . This law shall become effective from the date of its publication , save for Article CARDINAL - CARDINAL [ of the LAW ] , which shall become effective on DATE .

... CARDINAL . Decisions of the judicial divisions of ORG of GPE or of the ORG of ORG of GPE that were not challenged by way of supervisory review proceedings before this PERSON entered into force , as well as resolutions of ORG of GPE , shall be final but may be appealed against to ORG of GPE on the basis of and pursuant to the procedure prescribed by LAW of GPE . ”

CARDINAL . In accordance with LAW extended to disputes relating to civil , family , labour and cooperative legal relations , if CARDINAL of the parties to a dispute is a natural person ( unless these disputes are within the jurisdiction of other authorities ) . The jurisdiction of the civil courts also extended to administrative legal relations referred to in LAW ( complaints against acts of ORG authorities , juristic persons or public officials , complaints against decisions given in relation to religious organisations and other disputes involving administrative legal relations ) .

CARDINAL . In accordance with LAW ( which concerns enforcement proceedings ) , decisions of ORG bodies , adopted with regard to the ownership and use of religious LOC ( buildings ) and property are regarded as enforceable by ORG . Decisions of ORG were enforceable , without any court order , as they were equated to writs of execution issued on the basis of a judicial decision ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Under the LAW , religious organisations have the right to use property , land , buildings and LOC owned by the ORG , non - governmental organisations or citizens ( section CARDINAL , LAW Property Status of Religious Organisations ” ) . Such property can be transferred to religious organisations under lease agreements .

CARDINAL . In accordance with section CARDINAL of this Act , the use or ownership of religious LOC and property belonging to the ORG may be transferred without consideration on the basis of a decision of ORG . Religious LOC and property belonging to the ORG can be used jointly by CARDINAL or more religious communities if they consent . In the absence of consent , the ORG authority has to decide on the arrangements for the use of the LOC , by concluding separate agreements with each of the communities . Requests for the transfer of ownership of religious LOC or property or for their use without charge shall be examined within DATE of the date of receipt .

CARDINAL . Under the relevant subparagraphs of section CARDINAL , agreements on the use of religious LOC and other buildings and property may be terminated or suspended in accordance with the procedure and on the grounds specified in the civil legislation of GPE . Decisions of the ORG authorities with regard to the ownership and use of religious LOC and property may be appealed against to the courts , in accordance with LAW .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL these organisations have the right to own , use and dispose of their property . These rights are protected by law ( section CARDINAL ) . Under section CARDINAL religious organisations have the right to create , in accordance with the provisions of their statutes , publishing , commercial , agricultural and other enterprises and charitable institutions have the rights of a juristic person .

CARDINAL . In accordance with section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of this LAW , ORG is responsible for the enforcement of decisions of the ORG authorities adopted with regard to the ownership and use of religious LOC and property .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL ) of the Act states that the State Bailiff shall initiate enforcement proceedings upon request of the creditor or his representative in so far as it concerns the enforcement of CARDINAL of the decisions mentioned in LAW , on the basis of the writ of enforcement .

CARDINAL . The Practice Direction states that disputes that relate to the amendment , termination or enforcement of an agreement on the use of the LOC shall not be within the jurisdiction of the commercial ( former arbitration ) courts ( paragraph CARDINAL of the Practice Direction ) . It further establishes that decisions concerning the transfer of ownership of religious LOC or property may be appealed against to the commercial courts ( paragraph CARDINAL of ORG ) and are not within the jurisdiction of the courts of general jurisdiction . Moreover , under paragraph CARDINAL of ORG , the commercial courts must decline jurisdiction to hear actions for recovery of property improperly taken ( віндікаційні позови ) or actions to eliminate obstacles in free enjoyment of possessions ( негаторні позови ) , if a ORG authority has already adopted a decision on that issue in an “ enforceable document ” in accordance with the section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW .
CARDINAL . The relevant extracts from the Report read as follows :
“ ( ... ) F. Freedom of conscience and religion

( ... ) CARDINAL . GPE undertook to ( ... ) find a legal solution for the restitution of church property . The present PERSON on freedom of conscience and religious organisations dates back to DATE . Despite the fact that it is regarded as CARDINAL of the best freedom of religion laws in the region , some of its provisions lack clarity . ( ... ) The law also contains a number of other ambiguous provisions , which leave a wide discretion to the implementing authorities . Hence , the quite progressive law for the time of its adoption now requires significant rewording . ( ... )

CARDINAL . NORP The NORP legislation still lacks effective legal tools for restitution of church property . So far restitution was carried out occasionally on the basis of the parliament 's DATE resolution and several presidential decrees . The legal problem of restitution mainly stems from the fact that religious associations have no right to obtain a legal entity status and thus can not possess property . Most of the organisations , which owned the property that should be restituted , ceased to exist and ORG is represented by several organisations . This leads to an ad hoc restitution practice totally depending on the local authorities ' preferences and which in most cases entails not the return of the ownership rights but transfer of property into a gratis rent . We , therefore , call on the NORP authorities to elaborate clear rules on the restitution of religious property . ”
